*[http://www.livesandletters.ac.uk/rs/pilot/ref/biographies.html Letters] of the [[Royal Society]] *{{cite web|url=http://galileo.rice.edu/Catalog/NewFiles/hevelius.html|title=The Galileo Project|accessdate=24 August 2011| publisher = [[Rice University]]}} (in German also known as ''Hevel''; {{lang-pl|Jan Heweliusz}}; {{birth date|df=yes|1611|1|28}} – 28 January 1687) was a councillor and [[mayor]] of [[Danzig]] (Gdańsk), [[Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth|Kingdom of Poland]].Robert Bideleux, Ian Jeffries, ''A History of Eastern Europe: Crisis and Change'', Routledge, 1998, p. 124, {{ISBN|0-415-16112-6}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=IuW7T8wfNGAC&pg=PA124&dq=%22Royal+prussia%22+Poland+1466+Elbl%C4%85g&lr=lang_en&as_brr=3&hl=pl Google Books] As an [[astronomer]], he gained a reputation as "the founder of [[moon|lunar]] [[topography]]",{{EB1911 |inline=1 |last=Clerke |first=Agnes Mary|wstitle=Hevelius, Johann |volume=13 |pages=416–417}} and described ten new [[constellation]]s, seven of which are still used by astronomers.{{cite web| url = http://www.ianridpath.com/startales/startales1d.htm| title = Star Tales| accessdate = 2009-01-24| author = Ian Ridpath}} ==Etymology== According to the [[Polish Academy of Sciences]] (1975) the origin of the name goes back to the [[Hawke (surname)|surname Hawke]], a historical alternative spelling for the English word [[hawk]], which changed into ''Hawelke'' or ''Hawelecke''.''Historia astronomii w Polsce'': vol. 1 1975. Jerzy Dobrzycki, Eugeniusz Rybka, Polska Akademia Nauk. (Pracownia Historii Nauk ścisłych), page 256. {{OCLC|2776864}} In Poland he is known as ''Jan Heweliusz'',Older spellings include also Jan Hewelijusz and Jan Hefel, according to Samuel Orgelbrand, ed. 1884. ''Encyklopedyja powszechna S. Orgelbranda:nowe stereotypowe odbicie'', vols 5-6 page 243. {{OCLC|17568522}} According to [[Patrick Moore]] ''Hevelius'' is a Latinised version of the name ''Hewelcke''{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2FNfjWKBZx8C&pg=PA543&dq=johannes+hewelcke&hl=de&ei=VUJXTq7uFtDU4QSh_tnJDA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCoQ6AEwADgK#v=onepage&q=johannes%20hewelcke&f=false|title=Patrick Moore's Data Book of Astronomy|first1=Patrick|last1=Moore|first2=Robin|last2=Rees|publisher=Cambridge University Press |date=2011|isbn=0521899354|page=63,543|language=}} other versions of the name include Hewel,{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-gdTgIW-7IMC&pg=PA46&dq=johannes+hewel+hevelius&hl=de&ei=r0NXTtOSL4PSsgbKn7nGCg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CEgQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=johannes%20hewel%20hevelius&f=false|title=Histories of Scientific Insights|first1=Igor|last1=Ushakov|publisher= |date=2007|isbn=978-1-4303-2849-0|page=46|language=}} Hevel, Hevelke{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iWkyiEeiyksC&pg=PA126&dq=hewel+hevelius&hl=de&ei=AKZcTtPZKNDTsgaQ7LDEDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CE4Q6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=hewel%20hevelius&f=false|title=The sun recorded through history|first1=José M.|last1=Vaquero|first2=Manuel|last2=Vázquez|publisher=Springer |date=2009|isbn=9780387927909|page=126|language=}} or Hoefel,{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nTBIAAAAIAAJ&q=stellaeburgum+hevelius&dq=stellaeburgum+hevelius&hl=de&ei=KENfTteBLdHP4QTZ2yQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CFgQ6AEwCQ|title=Pieśń o Gdańsku|first1=Wiktor Teofil|last1=Gomulicki|publisher=Wydaw Morskie |date=1978|isbn=|page=80|language=Polish}} Höwelcke, Höfelcke.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gx2IFngILiAC&pg=PA998&dq=johannes+h%C3%B6welcke&hl=de&ei=mkVXTo_mH43Osgb2iJGXCw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CEcQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=johannes%20h%C3%B6welcke&f=false|title=Deutsch-polnische Beziehungen in Geschichte und Gegenwart|first1=Andreas |last1=Lawaty|first2=Anna|last2=Domańska|publisher=Deutsches Polen-Institut |date=2000|isbn=|page=998|language=German}} According to [[Feliks Bentkowski]] (1814) during his early years he also signed as Hoefelius,Bentkowski, 1814. ''Historya literatury polskiey: wystawiona w spisie dzieł drukiem ogłoszonych'', page 321. Ludwig Günther-Fürstenwalde (1903) reports, next to the usage of the Latinised version, Hevelius' signature as ''Johannes Höffelius Dantiscanus'' in 1631 and ''Hans Höwelcke'' in 1639.Ludwig Günther-Fürstenwalde, [https://archive.org/details/himmelunderde01unkngoog "Johannes Hevelius: Ein Lebensbild aus dem XVII. Jahrhundert"], ''Himmel und Erde: Illustrierte naturwissenschaftliche Monatsschrift '', '''15''' (1903), 529–542. ==Early life== Hevelius' father was Abraham Hewelke (1576–1649), his mother Kordula Hecker (1576–1655). They were German-speaking [[Lutheran]]s,{{cite web|url= http://galileo.rice.edu/Catalog/NewFiles/hevelius.html| title =The Galileo Project | accessdate=24 August 2011 | publisher=Rice University}} wealthy [[brewery|brewing]] [[merchant]]s of [[Bohemia]]n origin. As a young boy, Hevelius was sent to [[Gądecz]] (Gondecz) where he studied the [[Polish language]].Libri Gedanenses, Tomy 23-24, Polska Akademia Naukowa Biblioteka Gdańska Państwowe Wydawnictwo Naukowe, page 127, 2005. Hevelius brewed the famous [[Jopen]] beer, which also gave its name to the "Jopengasse"/"Jopejska" Street,Stanisław Kutrzeba, ''Gdańsk przeszlość i teraźniejszość'', Wydawnictwo Zakladu Narodowego im. Osslińskich, page 366, 1928: "jedna strona zamyka ulicę Jopejską". {{OCLC|14021052}}Jan Kilarski, ''Gdańsk'', Wydawnictwo Polskie, page 46, 1937. {{OCLC|26021672}} after 1945 renamed as Piwna Street (Beer Street),{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LMuuwvSxrj4C&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=Jopengasse&f=false |title=Neue Stadt in altem Glanz - Der Wiederaufbau Danzigs 1945-1960|first1=Jacek|last1=Friedrich|publisher=Böhlau |date=2010|isbn=3-412-20312-2|page=43|language=German}} where [[St. Mary's Church, Gdańsk|St. Mary's Church]] is located. After ''[[Gymnasium (school)|gymnasium]]'' (secondary school), where he was taught by [[Peter Crüger]], Hevelius in 1630 studied [[jurisprudence]] at [[Leiden University|Leiden]], then travelled in [[England]] and [[France]], meeting [[Pierre Gassendi]], [[Marin Mersenne]] and [[Athanasius Kircher]]. In 1634 he settled in his native town, and on 21 March 1635 married Katharine Rebeschke, a neighbour two years younger who owned two adjacent houses. The following year, Hevelius became a member of the [[beer]]-[[brewing]] [[guild]], which he led from 1643 onwards. ==Astronomy== [[File:Hevelius-Quadrant.jpg|thumb|150px|[[Peter Crüger]]'s [[azimuth]]al [[Quadrant (instrument)|quadrant]], completed by Hevelius]] Throughout his life, Hevelius took a leading part in [[municipal]] [[Local government|administration]], becoming [[town council]]lor in 1651; but from 1639 on, his chief interest was [[astronomy]]. In 1641 he built an [[observatory]] on the roofs of his three connected houses, equipping it with splendid instruments, ultimately including a large [[Keplerian Telescope|Keplerian telescope]] of {{convert|150|ft|m|abbr=on|order=flip}} [[focal length]], with a wood and wire tube he constructed himself. This may have been the longest "tubed" telescope before the advent of the tubeless [[aerial telescope]].[https://books.google.com/books?id=KAWwzHlDVksC&pg=PA50&lpg=PA50&dq=Johannes+Hevelius+Aerial+telescope&source=bl&ots=0GRN8hJX_3&sig=KKO2Fd35xNz7-tY6Y08I3R5bJ-U&hl=en&ei=TD8QSqjTL4Ss8QTJqfigBg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6#PPA53,M1 Henry C. King, Harold Spencer Jones - '''The history of the telescope''', page 53] [[File:Houghton Typ 620.73.451 - Johannes Hevelius, Machinae coelestis, 1673.jpg|thumb|left|250px|[[Woodcut]] of Hevelius' {{convert|150|ft|m|abbr=on|order=flip}} focal-length [[telescope]]]] The observatory was known by the name ''Sternenburg''{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0ZFXiNn62ZEC&pg=PA106&dq=sternenburg+hevelius&hl=de&ei=bDxfTrz-Neik4AT1y90y&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CDcQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=sternenburg%20hevelius&f=false|title=Celestial Treasury: from the music of the spheres to the conquest of space |first1=Marc|last1=Lachièze-Rey |first2=Jean-Pierre|last2=Luminet|publisher=Cambridge University Press|date=2001|isbn=0-521-80040-4|page=106|language=}}
{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KAWwzHlDVksC&pg=PA53&dq=sternenburg+hevelius&hl=de&ei=qFlfTs3_Oc774QTo7OwE&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CEgQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=sternen-burg%20&f=false |title=The history of the telescope |first1=Henry C.|last1=King|publisher=Courier Dover publ. |date=2003|isbn=0-486-43265-3|page=53|language=}}
{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sEyCQEqLAnIC&pg=PA182&dq=sternenburg+hevelius&hl=de&ei=4l5fTuayFcz74QSu14E4&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CE0Q6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=sternenburg%20hevelius&f=false|title=Unusual telescopes |first1=Peter L.|last1=Manly |publisher=Cambridge University Press|date=1995|isbn=0-521-48393-X|page=182|language=}}
{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?ei=4l5fTuayFcz74QSu14E4&ct=result&id=EOrbAAAAMAAJ&dq=sternenburg+hevelius&q=sternenburg+|title=Mirror mirror |first1=Mark|last1=Pendergrast |authorlink1=Mark Pendergrast |publisher= |date=2003|isbn= |page=96|language=}}
{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4mzvAAAAMAAJ&q=sternenburg+hevelius&dq=sternenburg+hevelius&hl=de&ei=4l5fTuayFcz74QSu14E4&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CFYQ6AEwCQ |title=Astronomy encyclopedia |first1=Patrick|last1=Moore|publisher=Oxford University Press |date=2002|isbn=|page=180|language=}} ({{lang-la|Stellaeburgum}}; {{lang-pl|Gwiezdny Zamek}}) or "Star Castle"[http://www.janheweliusz.pl/article/8901_Gdanski_dom_Jana_Heweliusza.htm Gdański dom Jana Heweliusza] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111202010849/http://www.janheweliusz.pl/article/8901_Gdanski_dom_Jana_Heweliusza.htm |date=2 December 2011 }} This private observatory was visited by Polish Queen [[Marie Louise Gonzaga]] on 29 January 1660. As a subject of the Polish kings, Hevelius enjoyed the patronage of four consecutive kings of Poland,Hippolit Skimborowicz: ''Żywot i prace Jana Hewelinsza gdańszczanina żyjacego pod panowaniem czterech królów polskich'', Warszawa 1860. {{OCLC|253951432}} and his family was raised to the position of nobility by the King of Poland [[Jan Kazimierz]] in 1660, who previously visited his observatory in 1659.Kwartalnik historii kultury materialnej, Tom 39, Instytut Historii Kultury Materialnej 1991 (Polska Akademia Nauk), page 159. While the noble status was not ratified by the Polish [[Sejm]] Hevelius's coat of arms includes the distinctive Polish royal crown.On the 300th anniversary of the death of Johannes Hevelius: book of The International Scientific Session, Robert Glȩbocki, Andrzej Zbierski, International Scientific Session, Ossolineum, The Polish Academy of Sciences, page 56, 1992. The [[Polish King]] [[John III Sobieski]] who regularly visited Hevelius numerous times in years 1677–1683 released him from paying taxes connected to brewing and allowed his beer to be sold freely outside the city limits.Międzynarodowy Rok Heweliusza 1987: dokumentacja obchodów trzechsetnej rocznicy śmierci Jana Heweliusza (1687-1987), page 10, 1990 Zakład Narodowy im Ossolińskich. In May 1679 the young Englishman [[Edmond Halley]] visited him as emissary of the [[Royal Society]], whose fellow Hevelius had been since 1664. The Royal Society considers him one of the first German fellows.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?ei=RfhQTsrtD8nxsgbywOy4Aw&ct=result&id=6p81AAAAIAAJ&dq=Hevelius+Royal+Society+German&q=Hevelius+|title=A brief history of the Royal Society|first1=Edward Neville|last1=da Costa Andrade |publisher=Royal Society|date=1960|page=24|isbn=|accessdate=21 August 2011|authorlink1=Edward Neville da Costa Andrade}} Małgorzata Czerniakowska (2005) writes that "Jan Heweliusz was the first Pole to be inducted into the Royal Society in London. This important event took place on 19th March 1664".[http://gnu.univ.gda.pl/~emcz/hewrs.html Jan Heweliusz i Royal Society Małgorzata Czerniakowska] Hevelius considered himself as being citizen of the Polish world (''civis Orbis Poloniae''){{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=N_gjCh1QT_IC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Piotr+Stefan+Wandycz&cd=3#v=onepage&q=hevelius&f=false|title=The price of freedom: a history of East Central Europe from the Middle Ages to the Present |first1=Piotr Stefan|last1=Wandycz|publisher=Routledge |date=2001|isbn=3-406-36798-4|page=81|language=}} and stated in a letter dated from 9 January 1681 that he was ''Civis orbis Poloni, qui in honorem patriae suae rei Literariae bono tot labores molestiasque, absit gloria, cum maximo facultatum suarum dispendio perduravit''-"citizen of Polish world who, for glory of his country and for the good of science, worked so much, and while not boasting much, executed his work with most effort per his abilities"Rocznik gdański, Tom 65,Gdańskie Towarzystwo Naukowe, Wydział Nauk Społecznych i Humanistycznych,page 135, 2005Aleksander Birkenmajer, ''Etudes d'histoire des sciences en Pologne: Choix d'articles par les rédacteurs'', Ossolineum, page 15, 1972. {{OCLC|758078}} [[File:The nova of 1670 recorded by Hevelius.jpg|thumb|The [[CK Vulpeculae|nova of 1670]] recorded by Hevelius,{{cite web|title=Colliding Stars Explain Enigmatic Seventeenth Century Explosion|url=http://www.eso.org/public/news/eso1511/|accessdate=18 June 2015}}]] Halley had been instructed by [[Robert Hooke]] and [[John Flamsteed]] to persuade Hevelius to use [[History of telescopes|telescopes]] for his measurements, yet Hevelius demonstrated that he could do well with only [[quadrant (instrument)|quadrant]] and [[alidade]]. He is thus considered the last astronomer to do major work without the use of a telescope.[https://books.google.com/books?id=QhjRFox0mKYC&pg=PA414&ots=CKygx0mGr0&dq=%2Bhevelius+%2Bdanzig&sig=UFIMY-R_iikjNUN5bIelFzEhwfw#PPA414,M1 Daintith, John, ''Biographical Encyclopedia of Scientists'', CRC Books, 1994] {{ISBN|0-7503-0287-9}} at Google Books Hevelius made observations of [[sunspots]], 1642–1645, devoted four years to charting the lunar surface, discovered the [[Moon]]'s [[libration]] in longitude, and published his results in ''[[Selenographia, sive Lunae descriptio]]'' (1647), a work which entitles him to be called "the founder of lunar [[topography]]". He discovered four [[comet]]s, in 1652, 1661 (probably [[Ikeya-Zhang]]), 1672 and 1677. These discoveries led to his thesis that such bodies revolve around the [[Sun]] in parabolic paths. [[Image:Hevelius and wife.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Johannes Hevelius and wife Elisabeth making observations]] A complex [[Halo (optical phenomenon)|halo phenomenon]] was observed by many in the city [[Sevenfold sun miracle|on 20 February 1661]], and was described by Hevelius in his ''Mercurius in Sole visus Gedani'' the following year. Katharine, his first wife, died in 1662, and a year later Hevelius married [[Elisabeth Hevelius|Elisabeth Hevelius née Koopmann]], the young daughter of a merchant family. The couple had four children. Elisabeth supported him, published two of his works after his death, and is considered the first female astronomer. His observatory, instruments and books were destroyed by fire on 26 September 1679. The catastrophe is described in the preface to his ''Annus climactericus'' (1685). He promptly repaired the damage enough to enable him to observe the great comet of December 1680. He named the constellation ''[[Sextans]]'' in memory of these lost instruments. [[File:Gdańsk, kościół św. Katarzyny, płyta nagrobna J.Heweliusza.jpg|thumb|Tombstone of Johannes Hevelius in [[St Catherine's Church, Gdańsk|St Catherine's Church in Gdańsk]]]] [[File:Jan Heweliusz Monument.jpg|thumb|Monument to Jan Heweliusz in modern Gdańsk]] [[File:Moon by Johannes hevelius 1645.PNG|thumb|Hevelius' [[map]] of the [[Moon]]]] In late 1683, in commemoration of the victory of Christian forces led by Polish King John III Sobieski at the [[Battle of Vienna]], he invented and named the constellation ''Scutum Sobiescianum'' (Sobieski's Shield), now called [[Scutum (constellation)|Scutum]]. This constellation first occurred publicly in his star atlas ''Firmamentum Sobiescianum'', that was [[printing press|printed]] in his own house at lavish expense, and he himself engraved many of the [[printing]] plates. His health had suffered from the shock of the 1679 fire and he died on his 76th birthday, 28 January 1687. Hevelius was buried in St. Catherine's Church in his hometown. Descendants of Hevelius live in [[Urzędów]] in Poland where they support local astronomy enthusiasts.[http://www.janheweliusz.pl/article/9851_Potomkowie_Jana_Heweliusza.htm Potomkowie Jana Heweliusza] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111201224447/http://www.janheweliusz.pl/article/9851_Potomkowie_Jana_Heweliusza.htm |date=1 December 2011 }} == Works == *''Selenographia'' (1647) *'' De nativa Saturni facie ejusque varis Phasibus'' (1656) *''Historiola Mirae'' (1662), in which he named the periodic variable star [[Cetus|Omicron Ceti]] "[[Mira]]", or "the Wonderful" *''[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=CKBQAAAAcAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=Mercurius+in+Sole+visus&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi4hbWttaDPAhUkM8AKHUAyDx8Q6AEIOTAE#v=onepage&q=Mercurius%20in%20Sole%20visus&f=false Mercurius in Sole visus Gedani]'' (1662), principally on the [[transit of Mercury]], but containing chapters on many other observations *''Prodromus cometicus'' (1665) *[https://www.loc.gov/resource/rbctos.2017gen14228/ ''Cometographia'' (1668)] *''Machina coelestis'' (first part, 1673), containing a description of his instruments; the second part (1679) is extremely rare, nearly the whole issue having perished in the conflagration of 1679. Hevelius description of his "naked eye" observation method in the first part of this work led to a dispute with Robert Hooke who claimed observations without telescopic sights were of little value.[http://www.gap-system.org/~history/Biographies/Hevelius_Johannes.html J J O'Connor and E F Robertson, '''Johannes Hevelius''', gap-system.org] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607183226/http://www.gap-system.org/~history/Biographies/Hevelius_Johannes.html |date=7 June 2011 }} * {{google books|xF9DAAAAcAAJ|Annus climactericus, sive rerum uranicarum observationum annus quadragesimus nonus|cover=1}} ([[1685 in science|1685]]), describes the fire of 1679, and includes observations made by Hevelius on the variable star [[Mira]] *''[[Prodromus Astronomiae]]'' (c.1690) an unfinished work posthumously published by Johannes wife Catherina Elisabetha Koopman Hevelius in three books including:[http://www.usno.navy.mil/USNO/library/historical/images-of-historical-objects-artwork-in-library/rare-books/pages/hevelius-prodromus-astronomiae The United States Naval Meteorology and Oceanography Command (NMOC), Hevelius - Prodromus astronomiae][https://books.google.com/books?id=fXNrb_v9q7MC&pg=PA164&lpg=PA164&dq=Catalogus+Stellarum+Fixarum&source=bl&ots=NRZAlGXBAM&sig=p9XD01YDPBXE8EmUzaIn645s--E&hl=en&ei=1BzFSvbXHMPBlAeMiJmSAw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1#v=onepage&q=Catalogus%20Stellarum%20Fixarum&f=false Nick Kanas, '''Star maps: history, artistry, and cartography''', page 164] :*''Prodromus'', preface and unpublished observations :*''Catalogus Stellarum Fixarum'' (dated 1687), catalog of 1564 stars :*''Firmamentum Sobiescianum sive Uranographia'' (dated 1687), an [[Star atlas|atlas]] of [[constellation]]s, 56 sheets, corresponding to his catalog, contains seven new constellations delineated by him which are still in use (plus some now considered obsolete): :::[[Canes Venatici]], [[Lacerta]], [[Leo Minor]], [[Lynx (constellation)|Lynx]], [[Scutum (constellation)|Scutum]], [[Sextans]], and [[Vulpecula]]. :::Obsolete: [[Cerberus (constellation)|Cerberus]], [[Mons Maenalus]], and [[Triangulum Minus]]. ==See also== {{Css Image Crop|Image = DAN-25-Danzig-10MIL Mark (1923).jpg|bSize = 235|cWidth = 235|cHeight = 122|oTop = 2|oLeft = 0|Location = right|Description= Hevelius depicted on a 10 million [[German Papiermark#German Papiermark of Danzig|papiermark]] note (1923).}} * [[ORP Heweliusz|Polish Navy Ship ''ORP Heweliusz'']] * Polish ferry [[MS Jan Heweliusz|MS ''Jan Heweliusz'']], which sank in 1993 * [[Hevelius (crater)]], Moon crater * [[5703 Hevelius]], asteroid * [[List of largest optical telescopes historically]] * [[IH Cassiopeiae]], a star designation used with some frequency, from his star map ==Notes== {{Reflist|group="note"}} ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} *[http://galileo.rice.edu/Catalog/NewFiles/hevelius.html Galileo Project on Hevelius] *[http://www.aihs-iahs.org/en/projects/hevelius Project to publish the correspondence of Hevelius at the International Academy of the History of Science] *[http://www.univie.ac.at/hwastro Electronic facsimile-editions of the rare book collection at the Vienna Institute of Astronomy] *{{pl icon}} [http://emmcz.w.interia.pl/heveliuswebpark/index.html Jan Heweliusz - Gdańszczanin Tysiąclecia] *''Prodromus astronomiae'' - in digital facsimile: **[https://polona.pl/item/436467 Digital Collection of the National Library of Poland : Prodromus Astronomiæ] **[http://lhldigital.lindahall.org/cdm4/document.php?CISOROOT=/astro_atlas&CISOPTR=1671&REC=11 ''Prodromus astronomiae'', 1690], scanned book, at [[Linda Hall Library]]. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20140725152002/http://www.artwis.com/articles/johann-hevelius-1611-1687/ Johann Hevelius - Forgotten Pioneer of the Pendulum Clock] *[http://www.atlascoelestis.com/6.htm Uranographia, Danzica 1690 da www.atlascoelestis.com] *[http://www.ianridpath.com/startales/hevelius.htm Hevelius's new constellations] *[https://findingaid.lib.byu.edu/viewItem/Vault%20MSS%20494 Johannes Hevelius letter to Johann Philipp von Wurtzelbau, MSS 494] at [https://sites.lib.byu.edu/sc/ L. Tom Perry Special Collections], [[Brigham Young University]] *[https://bibnum.obspm.fr/ark:/11287/1T1sQ Johannes Hevelius letters] at the [[Paris Observatory]] {{ConstellationsByHevelius}} {{Authority control}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hevelius, Johannes}} [[Category:1611 births]] [[Category:1687 deaths]] [[Category:German astronomers]] [[Category:Polish astronomers]] [[Category:People from Gdańsk]] [[Category:17th-century astronomers]] [[Category:17th-century Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth people]] [[Category:17th-century Polish businesspeople]] [[Category:Selenographers]] [[Category:Scientific instrument makers]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Society]] [[Category:Discoverers of comets]]

revision.text:
[[File:Map of USA AL.svg|thumb|Location of the [[state of Alabama]] in the [[United States of America]]]] This is a '''list of state symbols of [[Alabama]].''' The items on the list have been officially sanctioned by the [[Alabama Legislature]]. Alabama has a total of 41 official state emblems. The oldest of which is the [[Alabama State Bible]], from 1853;{{cite web | url =http://www.archives.state.al.us/emblems/st_bible.html | title = Alabama State Bible | date=November 15, 2007| accessdate =2008-01-20 | publisher = [[Alabama Department of Archives and History]] }} the most recently designated is the [[peach]], Alabama's state tree fruit, established in 2006. The state has no [[List of U.S. state nicknames|official nickname]], although "Heart of Dixie" was strongly promoted by the [[Alabama Chamber of Commerce]] in the 1940s and 1950s, and put on state [[license plate]]s.{{cite web | url =http://www.archives.state.al.us/emblems/Heart_of_Dixie.html | title = The Heart of Dixie | accessdate =2008-01-20 | date=March 30, 2007 | publisher = Alabama Department of Archives and History }}{{cite web | url =http://www.archives.state.al.us/emblems/emblems.html | title =Alabama Emblems, Symbols and Honors| accessdate =2008-01-20 | date=February 5, 2008 | publisher = Alabama Department of Archives and History }} ==Insignia== {| class="wikitable" |- ! width="20%" | Type ! width="40%" | Symbol ! width="15%" | Year ! width="15%" | Image |- |'''[[Bible]]''' |The [[Alabama State Bible]] |align="center"|1853 |align="center"| |- |'''[[Seals of the U.S. states|Great Seal]]''' |The [[Seal of Alabama]] |align="center"|1876{{cite web | url =http://www.archives.state.al.us/emblems/great_sl.html | title = Alabama Great Seal | accessdate =2008-01-20 | date=January 2, 2008 | publisher = Alabama Department of Archives and History }} |align="center"|[[File:Seal of Alabama.svg|100px|Alabama seal]] |- |'''[[Flags of the U.S. states|Flag]]''' |The [[flag of Alabama]] |align="center"|1895{{cite web | url =http://www.archives.state.al.us/emblems/st_flag.html | title = Alabama State Flag | accessdate =2008-01-20 | date=September 28, 2007 | publisher = Alabama Department of Archives and History }} |align="center"|[[File:Flag of Alabama.svg|100px|Alabama flag]] |- |'''[[Coat of arms]]''' |The [[coat of arms of Alabama]] |align="center"|1939{{cite web | url =http://www.archives.state.al.us/emblems/st_coa.html | title = Official Alabama Coat of Arms | accessdate =2008-01-20 | date=April 27, 2006 | publisher = Alabama Department of Archives and History }} |align="center"|[[File:Coat of arms of Alabama.svg|100px|Alabama coat of arms]] |- |'''Military Crest''' |The State Military Crest of Alabama |align="center"| |align="center"|[[File:Alabama_National_Guard_crest.svg|100px]] |- |'''[[List of U.S. state mottos|Motto]]''' |''[[Audemus jura nostra defendere]]''
We dare defend our rights |align="center"|1939{{cite web | url =http://www.archives.state.al.us/emblems/st_motto.html | title = Official Alabama Motto | accessdate =2008-01-20 | date=April 27, 2006 | publisher = Alabama Department of Archives and History }} |align="center"|[[File:Motto of Alabama.jpg|100px|Alabama Motto]] |- |'''[[Creed]]''' |[[Alabama state creed]] |align="center"|1939{{cite web | url =http://www.archives.state.al.us/emblems/st_creed.html | title = Alabama's Creed | accessdate =2008-01-20 | date=April 27, 2006 | publisher = Alabama Department of Archives and History }} |align="center"| |- |'''[[Mascot]]''' |[[Eastern tiger swallowtail]] |align="center"|1989{{cite web | url = http://www.archives.state.al.us/emblems/st_masct.html | title = Alabama Official Mascot and Butterfly | accessdate =2008-01-20 | date=November 17, 2003 | publisher = Alabama Department of Archives and History }} |align="center"|[[File:Eastern Tiger Swallowtail (Papilio glaucus).jpg|100px|Eastern tiger swallowtail]] |- |} ==Species== {| class="wikitable" |- ! width="20%" | Type ! width="40%" | Symbol ! width="15%" | Year ! width="15%" | Image |- |'''[[List of U.S. state birds|Bird]]''' |[[Northern flicker|Yellowhammer]] (yellow-shafted flicker)
''Colaptes auratus'' |align="center"|1933{{cite web | url = http://www.archives.state.al.us/emblems/st_bird.html | title = Alabama State Bird | accessdate =2008-01-20 | date=April 27, 2006 | publisher = Alabama Department of Archives and History }} |align="center"|[[File:Colaptes auratus auratus1.jpg|100px|Yellowhammer]] |- |'''[[List of U.S. state fish|Saltwater fish]]''' |[[Atlantic tarpon]]

[[File:SAM factory - Moscow, Russia - panoramio.jpg|thumb|alt=Old factory on a street with trolley tracks|The Moscow Calculating Machines Plant in 2010]] This is a '''list of computer hardware manufacturers in the [[Soviet Union]]''':
==List== Major Soviet hardware manufacturers and ministry affiliations in 1988:<ref name="goodman88">{{cite book|last1=Goodman|first1=Seymour E.|title=Global Trends in Computer Technology and Their Impact on Export Control|date=1988|publisher=National Academies|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wkErAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA129|language=en|pages=127–131|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171103122739/https://books.google.com/books?id=wkErAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA129|archivedate=2017-11-03|df=}}</ref>
===Ministry of the Electronics Industry=== *[[Elka Plant]] *[[Leningrad Svetlana Association]] *[[Exiton Plant]] in [[Pavlovskiy Posad]] (завод «Экситон») *[[Voronezh Elektronika Association]] ([[:ru:НПО «Электроника»|НПО «Электроника»]]) *[[Zelenograd Complex]]
===Ministry of Instrument Making=== *[[V. I. Lenin Kiev Elektronmash Production Association]] (Киевское производственное объединение «Электронмаш» им. В. И. Ленина) *[[Kiev Plant of Computers and Electronic Control Machines (VUM)]] (Киевский завод вычислительных и управляющих машин - ВУМ) *[[Kishinev Calculating Machine Plant]] *[[Kursk Calculating Machines Plant]] *[[Leningrad Electrical Machines Plant]] (Ленинградский Электромашиностроительный Завод) *[[Livny Experimental Factory of Computer Graphics]] (Ливенский завод средств машинной графики) *[[Moscow Elektronmash Scientific Production Association]] *[[Orel Computer Machines Plant]] *[[Ryazan Order of Lenin Factory of Calculating Analytical Machinery]] *[[Impulse Severodonetsk Scientific Production Association]] (Северодонецкое научно-производственное объединение «Импульс») *[[Smolensk Calculating Machine Factory]] *[[Taurage Calculating Machine Assemblies Plant]] (Tauragės skaičiavimo mašinų elementų gamykla) *[[Tbilisi Control Computer Works]] *[[Lenin Vilnius Computer Factory]] *[[Vilnius Sigma Association]] *[[Vinnytsia Terminal Plant]] (Завод «Терминал»)
===Ministry of Radio Technology=== *[[Kazan Computer Plant]] ([[:ru:Казанское производственное объединение вычислительных систем|Казанский завод ЭВМ]]) *[[Minsk Computer Technology Production Corporation]] (Минское производственное объединение вычислительной техники) *[[Moscow Calculating Machines Plant]] (SAM; [[:ru:Завод счётно-аналитических машин имени В. Д. Калмыкова|Московский завод счётно-аналитических машин]]) *[[Moscow Radio Plant]] (Московский Радиозавод) *[[Penza Computer Work]] ([[:ru:ФГУП «ППО ЭВТ»|Завод вычислительных электронных машин]]) *[[Yerevan Electronics Plant]] (Ереванский завод "Электрон")
==See also== * [[List of computer hardware manufacturers]]

{{Orphan|date=May 2014}}
This is a '''list of [[population genetics]] projects'''.
== Multiple populations ==
* [[1000 Genomes Project]] * [[HapMap Project]]
== Population based projects ==
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Country ! Name ! Details ! Reference |- | [[United Kingdom]] | [http://www.uk10k.org/ UK10K] | 4000 healthy British and 6000 with extreme health problems |<ref name='uk10k'>Kaye, Jane, et al. "Managing clinically significant findings in research: the UK10K example." European Journal of Human Genetics (2014). http://www.nature.com/ejhg/journal/vaop/ncurrent/full/ejhg2013290a.html</ref> |- | [[Netherlands]] | [http://www.nlgenome.nl/ GoNL] | 250 trios (father, mother and child) of [[Dutch people|Dutch]] descent |<ref name='gonl'>Boomsma, Dorret I., et al. "The Genome of the Netherlands: design, and project goals." European Journal of Human Genetics 22.2 (2014): 221-227. http://www.nature.com/ejhg/journal/v22/n2/full/ejhg2013118a.html</ref> |- | [[South Africa]] | NA | 1 from Southern [[Kalahari]], 3 from Northern Kalahari, 1 [[Bantu peoples|Bantu]] from South Africa |<ref name='Schuster'>Schuster, Stephan C., et al. "Complete Khoisan and Bantu genomes from southern Africa." Nature 463.7283 (2010): 943-947. http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v463/n7283/full/nature08795.html</ref> |- | [[Singapore]] | [http://www.statgen.nus.edu.sg/~SGVP/ Singapore Genome Variation Project] | 268 individuals from the [[Chinese people|Chinese]], [[Malay people|Malay]], and [[Indian people|Indian]] population groups in [[Southeast Asia]] |<ref name='SGVP'>{{cite journal | pmc = 2775604 | pmid=19700652 | doi=10.1101/gr.095000.109 | volume=19 | title=Singapore Genome Variation Project: a haplotype map of three Southeast Asian populations | year=2009 | journal=Genome Res. | pages=2154–62 | last1 = Teo | first1 = YY | last2 = Sim | first2 = X | last3 = Ong | first3 = RT | last4 = Tan | first4 = AK | last5 = Chen | first5 = J | last6 = Tantoso | first6 = E | last7 = Small | first7 = KS | last8 = Ku | first8 = CS | last9 = Lee | first9 = EJ | last10 = Seielstad | first10 = M | last11 = Chia | first11 = KS}}</ref> |- | [[Italy]] | [https://sardinia.irp.nia.nih.gov/ SardiNIA Project] | 2,000 sequenced [[Sardinian people]] |<ref name='sardinia'>List of publication from the Sardinia project: https://sardinia.irp.nia.nih.gov/Publications/publications.html</ref> |-
| [[Germany]] | [http://www.popgen.de/ PopGen] (German) | Genotyping of 10,000 [[Germans|German]] people |<ref name='popgen'>Krawczak, M., et al. "PopGen: population-based recruitment of patients and controls for the analysis of complex genotype-phenotype relationships." Public Health Genomics 9.1 (2006): 55-61.</ref> |}
== See also ==

revision.text:
The following are named after [[Paul Erdős]]:
* [[Paul Erdős Award]] of the World Federation of National Mathematics Competitions * [[Erdős Prize]] * [[Erdős Lectures]] * [[Anna and Paul Erdős postdoctoral Fellowship]] of the Mathematics Department of the [[Technion]] * [[Erdős number]] * [[Erdős cardinal]] * [[Erdős–Nicolas number]] * [[Erdős conjecture]] — a list of numerous conjectures named after Erdős; See also [[List of conjectures by Paul Erdős]]. ** [[Erdős–Turán conjecture on additive bases]] ** [[Erdős conjecture on arithmetic progressions]] ** [[Erdős distinct distances problem]] ** [[Cameron–Erdős conjecture]] ** [[Erdős–Burr conjecture]] ** [[Erdős–Faber–Lovász conjecture]] ** Erdős–Graham conjecture — see [[Erdős–Graham problem]] ** [[Erdős–Gyárfás conjecture]] ** [[Erdős–Straus conjecture]] ** [[Erdős–Szekeres conjecture]] ** [[Erdős–Turán conjecture]] * [[Copeland–Erdős constant]] * [[Erdős–Bacon number]] * [[Erdős–Borwein constant]] * [[Erdős–Diophantine graph]] * [[Erdős–Mordell inequality]] * [[Chung–Erdős inequality]] * [[Erdős–Rényi model]] * [[Erdős space]] * Erdős theorems ** [[de Bruijn–Erdős theorem (graph theory)]] ** [[de Bruijn–Erdős theorem (incidence geometry)]] ** [[Erdős–Anning theorem]] ** [[Erdős–Beck theorem]] ** [[Erdős–Dushnik–Miller theorem]] ** [[Erdős–Gallai theorem]] ** [[Erdős–Kac theorem]] ** [[Erdős–Ko–Rado theorem]] ** [[Erdős–Nagy theorem]] ** [[Erdős–Rado theorem]] ** [[Erdős–Stone theorem]] ** [[Erdős–Szekeres theorem]] ** [[Erdős–Szemerédi theorem]] * [[Erdős–Turán inequality]] * [[Erdős–Ulam problem]] * [[Erdős–Woods number]] * [[Hsu–Robbins–Erdős theorem]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:List of things named after Paul Erdos}} [[Category:Lists of things named after mathematicians|Erdos]] [[Category:Paul Erdős]]

{{Dynamic list}} This is a list of '''sources that each list metalloids''': elements classified as [[metalloid]]s. The sources are listed in chronological order. Lists of metalloids differ since there is no rigorous definition of metalloid (or its occasional alias, 'semi-metal'). Individual lists share common ground, with variations occurring at the margins. The elements most often regarded as metalloids are boron, silicon, germanium, arsenic, antimony and tellurium.{{#tag:ref|Lack of a rigorous definition: * Goldsmith RH 1982, 'Metalloids', ''Journal of Chemical Education'', vol. 59, no. 6, pp. 526–527, {{DOI|10.1021/ed059p526}} * Hawkes SJ 2001, 'Semimetallicity', ''Journal of Chemical Education,'' vol. 78, no. 12, pp. 1686–87, {{DOI|10.1021/ed078p1686}}|group=n}} Wikipedia generally categorises these six as metalloids, with the addition of astatine. Other sources may subtract from this list or add a varying number of other elements. ==Overview== {{periodic table (metalloid)}} {| class="wikitable sortable" cellpadding=0 border=1 style="font-size:85%; text-align:center;" |- ! colspan=2 | Element ! Citations ! Frequency |- ! colspan=2 |   ! style="font-size:85%;" | in ''n'' = 194

background:{{element color|metalloid citeclass 4 of 4}}"|Carbon |style="background:{{element color|metalloid citeclass 4 of 4}}; text-align:left"| C |style="background:{{element color|metalloid citeclass 4 of 4}}"|16.5 |style="background:{{element color|metalloid citeclass 4 of 4}}"|8.5% |- !style="text-align:left;" | Bismuth |style="text-align:left;" | Bi |11.5 |5.9% |- !style="text-align:left;" | Phosphorus |style="text-align:left;" | P |10 |5.2% |- !style="text-align:left;" | Beryllium |style="text-align:left;" | Be |7.5 |3.9% |- !style="text-align:left;" | Tin |style="text-align:left;" | Sn |5.5 |2.8% |- !style="text-align:left;" | Sulfur |style="text-align:left;" | S |3 |1.5% |- !style="text-align:left;" | Livermorium |style="text-align:left;" | Lv |3 |1.5% |- !style="text-align:left;" | Iodine |style="text-align:left;" | I |2.5 |1.3% |- !style="text-align:left;" | Flerovium |style="text-align:left;" | Fl |1 |0.5% |- !style="text-align:left;" | Gallium |style="text-align:left;" | Ga |1 |0.5% |- !style="text-align:left;" | Hydrogen |style="text-align:left;" | H |1 |0.5% |- !style="text-align:left;" | Lead |style="text-align:left;" | Pb |1 |0.5% |- !style="text-align:left;" | Moscovium |style="text-align:left;" | Mc |1 |0.5% |- !style="text-align:left;" | Tennessine |style="text-align:left;" | Ts |1 |0.5% |} ==Chronological list== This table show which elements are included in each of 194 different lists of metalloids. A parenthesized symbol indicates an element whose inclusion in a particular metalloid list is qualified in some way by the author(s). The 'citations' rows show how many and what percentage of the authorities consider each element to be a metalloid, with qualified citations counted as one-half. {{Periodic table (list of metalloid lists)}} There is an average of 7.15 elements per metalloid list. ==Appearance frequency clusters== [[File:Metalloid cluster frequencies.png|thumb|left|Clusters of elements and their appearance in the sources]] Elements cited in the listed sources (as of August 2011; ''n'' = 194) have appearance frequencies that occur in clusters of comparable values. The diamonds in the graph mark the mean appearance frequency of each cluster. '''Cluster 1''' (93%) = B, Si, Ge, As, Sb, Te; '''cluster 2''' (44%) = Po, At; '''cluster 3''' (24%) = Se; '''cluster 4''' (9%) = C, Al; '''cluster 5''' (5%) = Be, P, Bi; '''cluster 6''' (3%) = Sn; and '''cluster 7''' (1%) = H, Ga, S, I, Pb, Fl, Mc, Lv, Ts. The resulting geometric trend line has the formula y = 199.47e−0.7423x and an R2 value of 0.9962.{{#tag:ref|The [[Coefficient of determination|R2]] value is a measure of how close a formula fits a set of data points. Values fall between 0.0 and 1.0, with those near 1.0 indicating a good fit.|group=n}}{{clear}} ==Elements regarded as metalloids== The elements commonly classified as metalloids are boron, silicon, germanium, arsenic, antimony and tellurium.{{#tag:ref|Elements commonly classified as metalloids: * Goldsmith RH 1982, 'Metalloids', ''Journal of Chemical Education'', vol. 59, no. 6, pp. 526–7 (526), {{DOI|10.1021/ed059p526}} * Mann JB, Meek TL & Allen LC 2000, 'Configuration energies of the main group elements', ''Journal of the American Chemical Society,'' vol. 122, no. 12, pp. 2780–3 (2783), {{DOI|10.1021ja992866e}}: Mann et al. refer to these elements as 'the recognized metalloids'. * Kotz JC, Treichel P & Weaver GC 2009, ''Chemistry and Chemical Reactivity,'' 7th ed., Brooks/Cole, Belmont, California, {{ISBN|1439041318}}|group=n}} The status of polonium and astatine is not settled. Most authors recognise one or the other, or both, as metalloids; Herman, Hoffmann and Ashcroft, on the basis of relativistic modelling, predict astatine will be a monatomic metal.{{#tag:ref|Polonium and astatine: * Hawkes SJ 2001, 'Semimetallicity?', ''Journal of Chemical Education,'' vol. 78, no. 12, pp. 1686–87, {{DOI|10.1021/ed078p1686}} * Holt, Rinehart & Wilson c. 2007 [http://go.hrw.com/resources/go_sc/periodic/Po_At_Metalloids.pdf 'Why polonium and astatine are not metalloids in HRW texts'], viewed 8 February 2013 * Hawkes SJ 2010, 'Polonium and astatine are not semimetals', ''Journal of Chemical Education,'' vol. 87, no. 8, p. 783, {{DOI|10.1021ed100308w}} * Hermann A, Hoffmann R & Ashcroft NW 2013, 'Condensed Astatine: Monatomic and Metallic', ''Physical Review Letters,'' vol. 111, pp. 11604–1−11604-5, {{doi|10.1103/PhysRevLett.111.116404}} * Vernon RE 2013, 'Which Elements Are Metalloids?', ''Journal of Chemical Education,'' vol. 90, no. 12, pp. 1703–1707, {{doi|10.1021/ed3008457}}|group=n}} One or more of carbon, aluminium, phosphorus, selenium, tin or bismuth, these being periodic table neighbours of the elements commonly classified as metalloids, are sometimes recognised as metalloids.{{#tag:ref|Carbon, aluminium, phosphorus, selenium, tin, bismuth: * Rochow EG 1966, ''The metalloids,'' DC Heath and Company, Boston, pp. 7–8 * Cobb HM 2012, ''Dictionary of Metals,'' ASM International, Materials Park, OH, p. 145, {{ISBN|9781615039784}} * Walker CH 2012, ''Organic Pollutants: An Ecotoxicological Perspective,'' 2nd ed., CRC Press, Boca Raton, FL, p. 163, {{ISBN|9781420062588}} * Whiten K, Davis R, Peck L & Stanley G 2014, ''Chemistry,'' 10th ed., Brooks/Cole Cengage Learning, Belmont, CA, p. 134, {{ISBN|9781133610663}}|group=n}} Selenium, in particular, is commonly designated as a metalloid in [[environmental chemistry]]{{#tag:ref|Selenium as a metalloid in environmental chemistry: * Meyer JS, Adams WJ, Brix KV, Luoma SM, Mount DR, Stubblefield WA & Wood CM (eds) 2005, ''Toxicity of dietborne metals to aquatic organisms,'' Proceedings from the Pellston Workshop on Toxicity of Dietborne Metals to Aquatic Organisms, 27 July–1 August 2002, Fairmont Hot Springs, British Columbia, Canada, Society of Environmental Toxicology and Chemistry, Pensacola, Florida, p. 284, {{ISBN|1880611708}} * Weiner ER 2013, ''Applications of Environmental Aquatic Chemistry: A Practical Guide,'' 3rd ed., CRC Press, Boca Raton, FL, p. 181, {{ISBN|9781439853320}}|group=n}} on account of similarities in its aquatic chemistry with that of arsenic and antimony.{{#tag:ref|Similarities in the aquatic chemistry of selenium, arsenic, and antimony: * US Environmental Protection Agency 1988, ''Ambient aquatic life water quality criteria for antimony (III),'' draft, Office of Research and Development, Environmental Research Laboratories, Washington, p. 1 * De Zuane J 1997, ''Handbook of drinking water quality,'' 2nd ed., John Wiley & Sons, New York, p. 93, {{ISBN|047128789X}} * Uden PC 2005, 'Speciation of selenium,' in R Cornelis, J Caruso, H Crews & K Heumann (eds), ''Handbook of elemental speciation II: Species in the environment, food, medicine and occupational health,'' John Wiley & Sons, Chichester, pp. 346–65 (347–8), {{ISBN|0470855983}} * Dev N 2008, 'Modelling selenium fate and transport in Great Salt Lake Wetlands' PhD dissertation, University of Utah, ProQuest, Ann Arbor, Michigan, pp. 2–3, {{ISBN|054986542X}}|group=n}} There are fewer references to beryllium, in spite of its periodic table position adjoining the [[dividing line between metals and nonmetals]]. Isolated references in the literature can also be found to the categorisation of other elements as metalloids. These elements include: hydrogen, nitrogen,{{#tag:ref|Nitrogen: Rausch MD 1960, 'Cyclopentadienyl compounds of metals and metalloids', ''Journal of Chemical Education,'' vol. 37, no. 11, pp. 568–78, {{DOI|10.1021/ed037p568}}|group=n}} sulfur,{{#tag:ref|Sulfur: * Chalmers B 1959, ''Physical metallurgy,'' John Wiley & Sons, New York, p. 72 * US Bureau of Naval Personnel 1965, ''Shipfitter 3 & 2,'' US Government Printing Office, Washington, p. 26|group=n}} zinc,{{#tag:ref|Zinc: Siebring BR 1967, ''Chemistry,'' MacMillan, New York, p. 613|group=n}} gallium,{{#tag:ref|Gallium: Wiberg N 2001, [https://books.google.com/books?id=Mtth5g59dEIC&printsec=frontcover ''Inorganic chemistry],'' Academic Press, San Diego, p. 282, {{ISBN|0123526515}}|group=n}} iodine,{{#tag:ref|Iodine: * Friend JN 1953, ''Man and the chemical elements,'' 1st ed., Charles Scribner's Sons, New York, p. 68 * Rausch MD 1960, 'Cyclopentadienyl compounds of metals and metalloids', ''Journal of Chemical Education,'' vol. 37, no. 11, pp. 568–78, {{DOI|10.1021/ed037p568}}|group=n}} lead,{{#tag:ref|Lead: Murray JF 1928, 'Cable-sheath corrosion', ''Electrical World'', vol. 92, Dec 29, pp. 1295–7 (1295)|group=n}} and radon{{#tag:ref|Radon: * Hampel CA & Hawley GG 1966, ''The encyclopedia of chemistry,'' 3rd ed., Van Nostrand Reinhold, New York,p. 950 * Stein L 1985, 'New evidence that radon is a metalloid element: ion-exchange reactions of cationic radon', ''Journal of the Chemical Society, Chemical Communications,'' vol. 22, pp. 1631–2, {{DOI|10.1039/C39850001631}} * Stein L 1987, 'Chemical properties of radon' in PK Hopke (ed.) 1987, ''Radon and its decay products: Occurrence, properties, and health effects,'' American Chemical Society, Washington DC, pp. 240–51 (240, 247–8), {{ISBN|0841210152}}|group=n}} (citations are for references other than those listed above). ==Notes== {{Reflist|group=n}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2011}} {{Navbox periodic table}} [[Category:Metalloids]] [[Category:Lists of chemical elements|metalloid lists]]

revision.text:
'''Minimum Information Required About a Glycomics Experiment''' ('''MIRAGE''') is part of the [[Minimum Information Standards]] and specifically applies to guidelines for reporting (describing [[metadata]]) on a [[glycomics]] experiment. The initiative is supported by the [[Beilstein Institute for the Advancement of Chemical Sciences]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.beilstein-institut.de/en/projects/mirage|title=MIRAGE at the Beilstein Institute}}</ref> The project was launched in 2011 in Seattle and set off with the publication of the first set of guidelines for reporting [[mass spectrometry#Glycan_analysis|mass spectrometry-based glycan analysis]]. <ref name="The minimum information required for a glycomics experiment (MIRAGE) project: improving the standards for reporting mass-spectrometry-based glycoanalytic data">{{cite journal|title=The minimum information required for a glycomics experiment (MIRAGE) project: improving the standards for reporting mass-spectrometry-based glycoanalytic data|journal=Mol Cell Proteomics|date=Apr 2013|volume=12|issue=4|pages=991–995|doi=10.1074/mcp.O112.026492|pmid=23378518|pmc=3617344|last1=Kolarich|first1=D.|last2=Rapp|first2=E.|last3=Struwe|first3=W. B.|last4=Haslam|first4=S. M.|last5=Zaia|first5=J.|last6=McBride|first6=R.|last7=Agravat|first7=S.|last8=Campbell|first8=M. P.|last9=Kato|first9=M.|last10=Ranzinger|first10=R.|last11=Kettner|first11=C.|last12=York|first12=W. S.}}</ref>
Two other sets of guidelines have been published regarding sample preparation <ref name="The minimum information required for a glycomics experiment (MIRAGE) project: sample preparation guidelines for reliable reporting of glycomics datasets">{{cite journal|vauthors=Struwe et al|title=The minimum information required for a glycomics experiment (MIRAGE) project: sample preparation guidelines for reliable reporting of glycomics datasets|journal=Glycobiology|date=Sep 2016|volume=26|issue=9|pages=907–910|pmid=27654115|pmc=5045532|doi=10.1093/glycob/cww082}}</ref> and [[Glycan array|glycan array]] experiments <ref name="The minimum information required for a glycomics experiment (MIRAGE) project: improving the standards for reporting glycan microarray-based data">{{cite journal|vauthors=Liu et al|title=The minimum information required for a glycomics experiment (MIRAGE) project: improving the standards for reporting glycan microarray-based data|journal=Glycobiology|date=Apr 2017|volume=27|issue=4|pages=280–284|pmid=27993942|pmc=5444268|doi=10.1093/glycob/cww118}}</ref>
== References== <references />
==External links==
*[https://fairsharing.org/bsg-s000682 Record in Fairsharing.org for MIRAGE Sample Preparation guidelines] *[https://fairsharing.org/bsg-s000523 Record in Fairsharing.org for MIRAGE Mass spectrometry guidelines] *[https://fairsharing.org/bsg-s000683 Record in Fairsharing.org for MIRAGE Glycan array guidelines]

{{Infobox company | name = Plotly | logo = Plotly-logo-01-square.png | type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | industry = [[Computer software]] | foundation = [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]] (2012) | location_country = [[Canada]] | homepage = {{URL|https://plot.ly/}} }}
'''Plotly''', also known by its URL, '''Plot.ly''',<ref>{{Cite web|title = Plotly {{!}} Make charts and dashboards online|url = https://plot.ly/|website = plot.ly|accessdate = 2016-01-07}}</ref> is a technical computing company headquartered in [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]], that develops online [[data analytics]] and [[data visualization|visualization]] tools. Plotly provides online graphing, analytics, and statistics tools for individuals and collaboration, as well as scientific graphing libraries for [[Python (programming language)|Python]], [[R (programming language)|R]], [[MATLAB]], [[Perl]], [[Julia (programming language)|Julia]], [[Arduino]], and [[REST]].
== History == Plotly was founded by Alex Johnson, Jack Parmer, Chris Parmer, and Matthew Sundquist.<ref name="montrealgazette">{{cite news|url=http://www.montrealgazette.com/business/Silicon+Valley+kids+launch+startup+Montreal/8722310/story.html|title=Ex-Silicon Valley kids to launch web startup in Montreal|work=Montreal Gazette|last=Czikk|first=Joseph|date=July 29, 2013|access-date=2013-10-29|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131113041705/http://www.montrealgazette.com/business/Silicon+Valley+kids+launch+startup+Montreal/8722310/story.html#|archive-date=2013-11-13|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> The founders' backgrounds are in science, energy, and data analysis and visualization.<ref name="montrealgazette" /> Early employees include Christophe Viau, a Canadian software engineer and Ben Postlethwaite, a Canadian geophysicist.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://plot.ly/about |title=About |publisher=Plotly |date= |accessdate=2013-10-29}}</ref> Plotly was named one of the Top 20 Hottest Innovative Companies in Canada by the Canadian [[Innovation Exchange]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://ca.finance.yahoo.com/blogs/dashboard/cix-2013-celebrates-canada-innovation-economy-130113454.html|title=CIX 2013 celebrates Canada’s innovation economy | work=Yahoo! Finance Canada|last=Levy|first=Carmi|date=November 11, 2013}}</ref> Plotly was featured in "startup row" at [[PyCon]] 2013,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://pycon.blogspot.in/2013/03/announcing-our-startup-row-selections.html|title=Announcing Our Startup Row Selections | work=PyCon|last=Curtin|first=Brian|date=March 11, 2013}}</ref> and sponsored the [[SciPy]] 2018 conference.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://scipy2018.scipy.org/ehome/299527/648130/|title=Sponsors {{!}} SciPy 2018|access-date=2018-08-06}}</ref>
Plotly raised $5.5 million during its [[Series A round|Series A]] funding, led by MHS Capital, [[Siemens]] Venture Capital, [[Rho Capital Partners|Rho Ventures]], Real Ventures, and [[Silicon Valley Bank]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://betakit.com/plotly-raises-5-5-million-series-a-from-mhs-capital-real-ventures-others/|title=Plotly raises $5.5 million Series A from Rho Ventures, MHS Capital, Real Ventures, others|work=BetaKit|access-date=2018-08-06|language=en-CA}}</ref>
Google and NASA have used Plotly for data analytics,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://techvibes.com/2015/06/03/plotly-2015-06-03|title=Plotly Data Science Platform Used by NASA and Google Raises $5.5 Million|website=Techvibes|language=en-US|access-date=2018-08-06}}</ref> and The Boston Globe and Washington Post newsrooms have produced data journalism using Plotly.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2014/07/31/where-trucks-crash-storrow-and-memorial-drives/A1rQpXZtcV4PIPPmSDNxKI/story.html|title=Where trucks crash on Storrow and Memorial drives - The Boston Globe|work=BostonGlobe.com|access-date=2018-08-06}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2013/11/05/a-hunger-expert-explains-what-happens-now-that-food-stamps-are-cut/|title=A hunger expert explains what happens now that food stamps are cut|website=Washington Post|language=en|access-date=2018-08-06}}</ref>
== Products == Plotly's main products include: *'''Dash''' is an open-source Python framework for building [[web-based]] [[analytic applications]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://plot.ly/products/dash/|title=Dash by Plotly|access-date=2018-07-31}}</ref> *'''Dash DAQ''' is a non-open-source package for building data acquisition [[Graphical user interface|GUIs]] to use with scientific instruments. It is built on Dash.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.dashdaq.io/|title=Dash DAQ|date=2018-03-28|work=Dash DAQ|access-date=2018-07-31|language=en-US}}</ref> *'''Chart Studio''' has a graphical user interface for importing and analyzing data into a grid and using stats tools.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://blogs.computerworld.com/business-intelligenceanalytics/23078/beauty-and-brains-plotly-combines-dataviz-and-serious-statistical-analysis-cloud|title=Beauty and brains: Plotly combines dataviz and serious statistical analysis|work=Computer World|last=Machlis|first=Sharon|date=November 6, 2013|access-date=2013-11-07|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202232439/http://blogs.computerworld.com/business-intelligenceanalytics/23078/beauty-and-brains-plotly-combines-dataviz-and-serious-statistical-analysis-cloud#|archive-date=2013-12-02|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> Graphs can be embedded or downloaded. Mainly used to make creating graphs faster and more efficient. *'''API libraries''' for [[Python (programming language)|Python]],<ref>{{cite news|url=https://wiki.python.org/moin/NumericAndScientific/Plotting|title=Graphical Representations of Data | work=Python Wiki | date=November 4, 2013}}</ref> [[R (programming language)|R]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://plot.ly/r/ |title=Plotly's R Library |publisher=Plotly|date= |accessdate=2014-10-12}}</ref> [[MATLAB]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://plot.ly/matlab/ |title=Plotly's MATLAB library |publisher=Plotly|date= |accessdate=2014-10-12}}</ref> [[Node.js]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://plot.ly/nodejs/ |title=Plotly's Node.js library |publisher=Plotly|date= |accessdate=2014-10-12}}</ref> [[Julia (programming language)|Julia]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://plot.ly/julia/ |title=Plotly's Julia library |publisher=Plotly|date= |accessdate=2014-10-12}}</ref> and [[Arduino]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://blog.arduino.cc/2013/11/04/create-interactive-graphs-logging-arduino-data-with-plotly/|title=Create Interactive Graphs Logging Arduino Data With Plotly | work=Arduino Blog|last=Romano|first=Zoe|date=November 4, 2013}}</ref> and a [[REST]] API.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://plot.ly/api |title=APIs |publisher=Plotly |date= |accessdate=2013-10-29}}</ref> Plotly can also be used to style interactive graphs with [[Project Jupyter|Jupyter notebook]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nbviewer.ipython.org/github/plotly/IPython-plotly/tree/master/ |publisher=IPython Notebook Viewer |title= Plotly IPython gallery |date= |accessdate=2013-12-10}}</ref> *'''Figure Converters''' which convert [[matplotlib]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://plot.ly/matplotlib/ |title=Online, interactive Matplotlib graphs |publisher=Plotly|date= |accessdate=2014-10-12}}</ref> [[ggplot2]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://plot.ly/ggplot2/ |title=Online, interactive ggplot2 graphs |publisher=Plotly|date= |accessdate=2014-10-12}}</ref> and [[IGOR Pro]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://github.com/plotly/Igor-Pro-Graph-Converter |title=Online, interactive Igor Pro graphs |publisher=Plotly|date= |accessdate=2014-10-12}}</ref> graphs into interactive, online graphs. *'''Plotly Apps''' for [[Google Chrome]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/plotly/khajkhinhblhaenlhpodnblkmpdgclne |title=Plotly |publisher=Google Chrome Store|date= |accessdate=2013-10-29}}</ref> *'''Plotly.js''' is an open source<ref>{{cite web|url=https://plot.ly/javascript/open-source-announcement|title=Open source announcement|accessdate=2015-11-17}}</ref> [[JavaScript]] library for creating graphs and dashboards.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://plot.ly/javascript/|title=plotly.js |publisher=Plotly |date= |accessdate=2013-10-29}}</ref> *'''Plotly Enterprise''' an on-premises installation of Plotly.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://plot.ly/product/enterprise/|title=Plotly Enterprise |publisher=Plotly |date= |accessdate=2014-09-20}}</ref>
[[File:Gallery of Plotly Graphs.png|thumb|right|A gallery of Plotly graphs]]
== Technology == Plotly was built using [[Python (programming language)|Python]] and the [[Django (web framework)|Django]] framework, with a front end using [[JavaScript]] and the visualization library [[D3.js]], [[HTML]] and [[CSS]]. Files are hosted on [[Amazon S3]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://blogs.computerworld.com/business-intelligenceanalytics/23078/beauty-and-brains-plotly-combines-dataviz-and-serious-statistical-analysis-cloud/|title=Beauty and brains: Plotly combines dataviz and serious statistical analysis|work=Computer World|last=Machlis|first=Sharon|date=November 6, 2013}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
== See also == * [[matplotlib]] * Visualization of [[FEATool Multiphysics|FEA simulation]] results with Plotly<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.featool.com/tutorial/2017/09/06/Matlab-Plotly-3D-Unstructured-Visualizations.html|title=3D FEM visualization with Plotly and the FEATool Multiphysics MATLAB Toolbox}}</ref>

without payload | alt-height = | diameter = {{convert|21.67|ft|m|abbr=on}} | alt-diameter = | mass = {{convert|1,300,220|lb|kg|abbr=on}}
without payload{{cite web |url=http://www.astronautix.com/lvs/saturnib.htm |title=Saturn IB |access-date=March 17, 2011 |author=Wade, Mark |work=Encyclopedia Astronautica |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110514030644/http://www.astronautix.com/lvs/saturnib.htm |archivedate=May 14, 2011 |df= }} | alt-mass = | stages = 2 | LEO-payload = {{convert|46,000|lb|kg|abbr=on}}{{cite book|last1=Hornung|first1=John|title=Entering the Race to the Moon: Autobiography of an Apollo Rocket Scientist|date=2013|publisher=Jack Be Nimble Publishing|location=Williamsburg, Virginia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MsrJy8mmPv0C&pg=PT207&lpg=PT207&dq=Entering+the+Race+to+the+Moon,+Saturn+IB+Established+Its+Place+in+Space&source=bl&ots=i7st8vZ7gj&sig=pzpCZUdSREgiT1F1nJzDzyX10W4&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjX8o6RmNzKAhUBJnIKHdHBA7kQ6AEILjAD#v=onepage&q=Entering%20the%20Race%20to%20the%20Moon%2C%20Saturn%20IB%20Established%20Its%20Place%20in%20Space&f=false}} | alt-LEO = | status = Retired | sites = [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Launch Complex 37|LC-37]] & [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Launch Complex 34|LC-34]], [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral]]
[[Kennedy Space Center Launch Complex 39|LC-39B]], [[Kennedy Space Center]] | launches = 9 | success = 9 | fail = 0 | payloads = Unmanned [[Apollo CSM]]
Unmanned [[Apollo LM]]
Manned Apollo CSM | first=February 26, 1966 | last=July 15, 1975 | stagedata = {{Infobox rocket/stage | type = stage | diff = | stageno = First | name = [[S-IB]] | length = {{convert|80.17|ft|m}} | diameter = {{convert|21.42|ft|m}} | width = | empty = {{convert|92500|lb|kg}} | gross = {{convert|973000|lb|kg}} | propmass = {{convert|880500|lb|kg}} | engines = 8 × [[Rocketdyne H-1]] | thrust = {{convert|1,600,000|lbf|kN|abbr=on}} | SI = {{convert|272|isp}} | burntime = 150 seconds | fuel = [[RP-1]] / [[LOX]] }} {{Infobox rocket/stage | type = stage | diff = | stageno = Second | name = [[S-IVB]]-200 | length = {{convert|58.42|ft|m}} | diameter = {{convert|21.42|ft|m}} | empty = {{convert|23400|lb|kg}} | gross = {{convert|251900|lb|kg}} | propmass = {{convert|228500|lb|kg}} | engines = [[Rocketdyne J-2]] | thrust = {{convert|200,000|lbf|kN|abbr=on}} | SI = {{convert|420|isp}} | burntime = 480 seconds | fuel = [[LH2|LH2]] / [[LOX]] }} }} The '''Saturn IB''' (pronounced "one B", also known as the '''Uprated Saturn I''') was an American launch vehicle commissioned by the [[NASA|National Aeronautics and Space Administration]] (NASA) for the [[Apollo program]]. It replaced the [[S-IV]] second stage of the [[Saturn I]] with the much more powerful [[S-IVB]], able to launch a partially fueled [[Apollo Command/Service Module]] (CSM) or a fully fueled [[Apollo Lunar Module|Lunar Module]] (LM) into [[low Earth orbit]] for early flight tests before the larger [[Saturn V]] needed for lunar flight was ready. By sharing the S-IVB upper stage, the Saturn IB and Saturn V provided a common interface to the Apollo spacecraft. The only major difference was that the S-IVB on the Saturn V burned only part of its propellant to achieve Earth orbit, so it could be restarted for [[trans-lunar injection]]. The S-IVB on the Saturn IB needed all of its propellant to achieve Earth orbit. The Saturn IB launched two unmanned CSM suborbital flights, one unmanned LM orbital flight, and the first manned CSM orbital mission (first planned as [[Apollo 1]], later flown as [[Apollo 7]]). It also launched one orbital mission, [[AS-203]], without a payload so the S-IVB would have residual [[liquid hydrogen]] fuel. This mission supported the design of the restartable version of the S-IVB used in the Saturn V, by observing the behavior of the liquid hydrogen in [[weightlessness]]. In 1973, the year after the Apollo lunar program ended, three Apollo CSM/Saturn IBs ferried crews to the [[Skylab]] space station. In 1975, one last Apollo/Saturn IB launched the Apollo portion of the joint US-[[Soviet Union|USSR]] [[Apollo–Soyuz Test Project]] (ASTP). A backup Apollo CSM/Saturn IB was assembled and made ready for a Skylab rescue mission, but never flown. The remaining Saturn IBs in NASA's inventory were scrapped after the ASTP mission, as no use could be found for them and all heavy lift needs of the US space program could be serviced by the cheaper and more versatile [[Titan (rocket family)|Titan III family]]. ==History== In 1959, NASA's [[Silverstein Committee]] issued recommendations to develop the [[Saturn (rocket family)|Saturn class]] launch vehicles, growing from the [[Saturn I|C-1]]. When the [[Apollo program]] was started in 1961 with the goal of landing men on the Moon, NASA chose the Saturn I for Earth orbital test missions. However, the Saturn I's payload limit of {{convert|20000|lb|kg}} would allow testing of only the Command Module with a smaller propulsion module attached, as the [[Apollo Command/Service Module]] would have a dry weight of at least {{convert|26300|lb|kg}}, in addition to service propulsion and reaction control fuel. In July 1962, NASA announced selection of the [[Saturn V|C-5]] for the lunar landing mission, and decided to develop another launch vehicle by upgrading the Saturn I, replacing its [[S-IV]] second stage with the [[S-IVB]], which would also be modified for use as the Saturn V third stage. The [[S-I]] first stage would also be upgraded to the S-IB by improving the thrust of its engines and removing some weight. The new Saturn IB, with a payload capability of at least {{convert|16000|kg|lb|order=flip}},{{cite book |last1=Benson |first1=Charles D. |last2=Faherty |first2=William Barnaby |title=Moonport: A History of Apollo Launch Facilities and Operations |date=1978 |publisher=NASA |url=http://www.hq.nasa.gov/office/pao/History/SP-4204/ch17-3.html |chapter=The Apollo-Saturn IB Space Vehicle |access-date=3 February 2016}} would replace the Saturn I for Earth orbit testing, allowing the Command/Service Module to be flown with a partial fuel load. It would also allow launching the {{convert|32000|lb|kg|adj=on}} [[Apollo Lunar Module|Lunar Excursion Module]] separately for unmanned and manned Earth orbital testing, before the Saturn V was ready to be flown. It would also give early development to the third stage. On May 12, 1966, NASA announced the vehicle's name would be changed to the "Uprated Saturn I", at the same time the "Lunar Excursion Module" was renamed the Lunar Module. However, the "Uprated Saturn I" name was reverted to Saturn IB on December 2, 1967. By the time it was developed, the Saturn IB payload capability had increased to {{convert|41000|lb|kg}}. By 1973, when it was used to launch three [[Skylab]] missions, the first-stage engine had been upgraded further, raising the payload capability to {{convert|46000|lb|kg}}. ==Specifications== ===Launch vehicle=== {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! '''Parameter'''{{Citation |title = Postlaunch report for mission AS-201 (Apollo spacecraft 009) - |publisher = NASA |date = May 1966 |url = https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/19750065090_1975065090.pdf |access-date = March 18, 2011}} ! '''S-IB 1st Stage''' ! '''S-IVB-200 2nd Stage''' ! '''Instrument Unit''' |- | Height | {{convert|80.17|ft|m|abbr=on}} | {{convert|58.42|ft|m|abbr=on}} | {{convert|3.00|ft|m|abbr=on}} |- | Diameter | {{convert|21.42|ft|m|abbr=on}} | {{convert|21.67|ft|m|abbr=on}} | {{convert|21.67|ft|m|abbr=on}} |- | Structural mass | {{convert|92,500|lb|kg|abbr=on}} | {{convert|23,400|lb|kg|abbr=on}} | {{convert|4,400|lb|kg|abbr=on}} |- | Propellant | RP-1 / LOX | LH2 / LOX | N/A |- | Propellant mass | {{convert|880,500|lb|kg|abbr=on}} | {{convert|228,500|lb|kg|abbr=on}} | N/A |- | Engines | Eight - H-1 | One - J-2 | N/A |- | Thrust | {{convert|1,600,000|lbf|kN|abbr=on}} sea level | {{convert|200,000|lbf|kN|abbr=on}} vacuum | N/A |- | Burn duration | 150 s | 480 s | N/A |- | Specific impulse | 272 s (2.66 kN·s/kg) sea level | 420 s (4.12 kN·s/kg) vacuum | N/A |- | Contractor | Chrysler | Douglas | IBM |} ===Payload configurations=== {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! '''Parameter''' ! '''Command/Service Module''' ! '''[[Apollo 5]]''' ! '''[[AS-203]]''' |- | [[Apollo Spacecraft#Launch Escape System (LES)|Launch Escape System]] mass | {{convert|9,200|lb|kg|abbr=on}} | N/A | N/A |- | [[Apollo Command/Service Module]] mass | {{convert|36,400|lb|kg|abbr=on}} to
{{convert|46,000|lb|kg|abbr=on}} | N/A | N/A |- | [[Apollo Lunar Module]] mass | N/A | {{convert|31,650|lb|kg|abbr=on}} | N/A |- | [[Apollo Spacecraft#Spacecraft Lunar Module Adapter (SLA)|Spacecraft LM Adapter]] mass | {{convert|4,050|lb|kg|abbr=on}} | {{convert|4,050|lb|kg|abbr=on}} | N/A |- | [[Nose cone]] height | N/A | {{convert|8.3|ft|m|abbr=on}} | {{convert|27.7|ft|m|abbr=on}} |- | Payload height | {{convert|81.8|ft|m|abbr=on}} | {{convert|36.3|ft|m|abbr=on}} | N/A |- | Total space vehicle height | {{convert|223.4|ft|m|abbr=on}} | {{convert|177.9|ft|m|abbr=on}} | {{convert|169.4|ft|m|abbr=on}} |} ==S-IB stage== {{Main|S-IB}} [[File:Saturn IB 1st stage.jpg|right|thumb|300px|Diagram of the S-IB first stage of the Saturn IB rocket]] The S-IB stage was built by the [[Chrysler]] corporation at the [[Michoud Assembly Facility]], [[New Orleans, Louisiana|New Orleans]]. It was powered by eight [[Rocketdyne H-1]] rocket engines burning [[RP-1]] fuel with [[liquid oxygen]] (LOX). Eight [[PGM-11 Redstone|Redstone]] tanks (four holding fuel and four holding LOX) were clustered around a [[PGM-19 Jupiter|Jupiter rocket]] LOX tank. The four outboard engines were mounted on [[gimbal]]s, allowing them to be steered to control the rocket. Eight fins surrounding the base thrust structure provided aerodynamic stability and control. *Height: {{convert|80.17|ft|m|abbr=on}} *Diameter: {{convert|21.42|ft|m|abbr=on}} *Number of fins: 8 *Finspan: {{convert|39.42|ft|m|abbr=on}} *Engines: 8 [[Rocketdyne H-1]] *Thrust: {{convert|1,600,000|lbf|kN|abbr=on}} *Fuel: [[RP-1]] (Refined [[kerosene]]) 41,000 US gal (155 m3) *Oxidizer: Liquid [[oxygen]] ([[LOX]]) 66,277 US gal (251 m3) nominal capacity including 1.5% ullage volume (43,284 US gal / 163 m3 in four outer tanks plus 22,993 US gal / 87 m3 in center tankNASA Marshall Spaceflight Center, Skylab Saturn IB Flight Manual (MSFC-MAN-206), 30 September 1972) *Burn time: 2.5 min *Burnout altitude: {{convert|37|nmi|km|abbr=on}} ==S-IVB-200 stage== {{Main|S-IVB}} [[File:Saturn S-IB SIV-B.jpg|right|thumb|300px|Diagram of the S-IVB second stage of the Saturn IB]] The S-IVB was built by the [[Douglas Aircraft Company]] at [[Huntington Beach, California]]. The S-IVB-200 model was similar to the S-IVB-500 third stage used on the [[Saturn V]], with the exception of the interstage adapter, smaller auxiliary propulsion control modules, and lack of on-orbit engine restart capability. It was powered by a single [[Rocketdyne J-2]] engine. The fuel and oxidizer tanks shared a common bulkhead, which saved about ten tons of weight and reduced vehicle length over ten feet. *Height: {{convert|58.42|ft|m|abbr=on}} *Diameter: {{convert|21.67|ft|m|abbr=on}} *Engine: single J-2 *Thrust: {{convert|200,000|lbf|kN|abbr=on}} *Fuel: Liquid [[hydrogen]] ([[LH2|LH2]]) 64,000 US gal (242 m3) *Oxidizer: Liquid [[oxygen]] ([[LOX]]) 20,000 US gal (76 m3) *Burn time: approx. 7 min *Burnout altitude (for Saturn IB): orbit ==Instrument Unit== {{Main|Saturn V Instrument Unit}} [[File:IU-501 From Below.jpg|right|thumb|The Instrument Unit, which controlled the Saturn IB and Saturn V]] [[IBM]] built the Instrument Unit at the Space Systems Center in [[Huntsville, Alabama]]. Located at the top of the S-IVB stage, it consisted of a Launch Vehicle Digital Computer (LVDC), an inertial platform, accelerometers, a tracking, telemetry and command system and associated environmental controls. It controlled the entire rocket from just before liftoff until battery depletion. Like other rocket guidance systems, it maintained its [[orbital state vectors|state vector]] (position and velocity estimates) by integrating accelerometer measurements, sent firing and steering commands to the main engines and auxiliary thrusters, and fired the appropriate ordnance and solid rocket motors during staging and payload separation events. As with other rockets, a completely independent and redundant [[range safety]] system could be invoked by ground radio command to terminate thrust and to destroy the vehicle should it malfunction and threaten people or property on the ground. In the Saturn IB and V, the range safety system was permanently disabled by ground command after safely reaching orbit. This was done to ensure that the S-IVB stage would not inadvertently rupture and create a cloud of debris in orbit that could endanger the crew of the Apollo CSM. ==Launch sequence events== {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! '''Launch event''' ! '''Time (s)''' ! '''Altitude (km)''' ! '''Range (km)''' |- | Ignition Command | -3.02 |. |. |- | First Motion | -0.19 |. |. |- | Liftoff | 0.00 |. |. |- | Initiate Pitch Maneuver | 10.0 |. |. |- | Initiate Roll Maneuver | 10.0 |. |. |- | End Roll Maneuver | 38.0 |. |. |- | Mach One | 62.18 | 7.63 |. |- | Max Q | 75.5 | 12.16 |. |- | Freeze Tilt | 134.40 |. |. |- | Inboard Engine Cutoff | 140.65 | . | . |- | Outboard Engine Cutoff | 144.32 | . | . |- | Ullage Rockets Ignition | 145.37 | . | . |- | S-IB / S-IVB Separation | 145.59 |. |. |- | S-IVB Ignition | 146.97 |. |. |- | Ullage Rocket Burnout | 148.33 |. |. |- | Ullage Rocket Jettison | 156.58 |. |. |- | Jettison LES | 163.28 |. |. |- | Start Pitch Over | 613.95 | . | . |- | S-IVB Cutoff | 616.76 | . | . |- | Orbit Insertion | 626.76 |. |. |- | Start S/C Sep Sequence | 663.11 |. |. |- | Spacecraft Separation | 728.31 |. |. |} ==Saturn IB vehicles and launches== [[File:ASTP Saturn IB.jpg|thumb|Saturn IB mounted on the "milkstool" platform]] The first five Saturn IB launches for the Apollo program were made from [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Launch Complex 34|LC-34]] and [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Launch Complex 37|LC-37]], [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Kennedy Air Force Station]]. The Saturn IB was used between 1973 and 1975 for three manned [[Skylab]] flights, and one [[Apollo-Soyuz Test Project]] flight. This final production run did not have alternating black and white S-IB stage tanks, or vertical stripes on the S-IVB aft tank skirt, which were present on the earlier vehicles. Since LC-34 and 37 were inactive by then, these launches utilized [[Kennedy Space Center Launch Complex 39|Kennedy Space Center's LC-39B]].{{cite book|last=Reynolds|first=David West|title=Kennedy Space Center: Gateway to Space|year=2006|publisher=Firefly Books Ltd.|location=Richmond Hill, Ontario|isbn=978-1-55407-039-8|pages=154–157}} [[Mobile Launcher Platform 3|Mobile Launcher Platform]] No. 1 was modified, adding an elevated platform known as the "milkstool" to accommodate the height differential between the Saturn IB and the much larger Saturn V. This enabled alignment of the Launch Umbilical Tower's access arms to accommodate crew access, fueling, and ground electrical connections for the Apollo spacecraft and S-IVB upper stage. The tower's second stage access arms were modified to service the S-IB first stage. used Apollo 1 launch vehicle |- | align=center| '''SA-205''' | align=center| [[Apollo 7]] | align=center| 16,520 | align=right| October 11, 1968 | Manned orbital test of Block II CSM |- | align=center| '''SA-206''' | align=center| [[Skylab 2]] | align=center| 19,979 | align=right| May 25, 1973 | Block II CSM ferried first crew to Skylab orbital workshop |- | align=center| '''SA-207''' | align=center| [[Skylab 3]] | align=center| 20,121 | align=right| July 28, 1973 | Block II CSM ferried second crew to Skylab orbital workshop |- | rowspan=2 align=center| '''SA-208''' | align=center| [[Skylab Rescue|AS-208]] | colspan=2| | Standby Skylab 3 rescue CSM-119; not needed |- | align=center| [[Skylab 4]] | align=center| 20,847 | align=right| November 16, 1973 | Block II CSM ferried third crew to Skylab orbital workshop |- | rowspan=2 align=center| '''SA-209''' | align=center| [[Skylab Rescue|AS-209]] | colspan=2| | Standby Skylab 4 and later Apollo-Soyuz rescue CSM-119.
Not needed, currently on display in the [[Kennedy Space Center Visitor Complex#Rocket garden|KSC rocket garden]] |- | align=center| [[Skylab 5]] | colspan=2| | Planned CSM mission to lift Skylab workshop's orbit
to endure until [[Space Shuttle]] ready to fly; cancelled. |- | align=center| '''SA-210''' | align=center| [[Apollo Soyuz Test Project|ASTP]] | align=center| 16,780 | align=right| July 15, 1975 | Apollo CSM with special docking adapter module,
rendezvoused with Soyuz 19. Last Saturn IB flight. |- | align=center| '''SA-211''' | colspan=3| | Unused. First stage at the Alabama Welcome Center on I-65 in Ardmore, Alabama.
S-IVB stage rests with Skylab underwater training simulator hardware and
is on display outdoors at the U.S. Space and Rocket Center in Huntsville, Alabama. |- | align=center| '''SA-212''' | colspan=3| | Unused. First stage scrapped.{{cite web |url=http://www.spacelaunchreport.com/satstg2.html |title=Saturn IB History |access-date=2009-11-01}}
S-IVB stage converted to [[Skylab]] space station. |- | align=center| '''SA-213''' | colspan=3| | Only first stage built. Unused and scrapped. |- | align=center| '''SA-214''' | colspan=3| | Only first stage built. Unused and scrapped. |} For earlier launches of vehicles in the Saturn I series, see the list in the [[Saturn I]] article. ===Saturn IB rockets on display=== [[File:Saturn IB at KSC.jpg|right|thumb|SA-209 on display at KSC]] Currently there are three locations where Saturn IB vehicles (or parts thereof) are on display: *SA-209 is on display at the [[Kennedy Space Center Visitor Complex]], with the Apollo Facilities Verification Vehicle. Due to severe corrosion, the first stage engines and Service Module were replaced with fabricated duplicates in 1993–1994. *The SA-211 first stage is on display with the [[S-IVB]]-S "Battleship" static test stage stacked in a launch-ready condition at the Alabama Welcome Center on [[Interstate 65]] in [[Ardmore, Alabama]]. {{Coord|34.954548|-86.89193|display=inline|region:US-AL_type:landmark}}{{cite news |first=Dave |last=Dooling |newspaper=[[The Huntsville Times]] |title=Space and Rocket Plans Summer Celebration |date=May 6, 1979 }}{{cite news |first=Bayne |last=Hughes |newspaper=[[The Decatur Daily]] |title=Iconic rocket due for repair |url=http://www.decaturdaily.com/news/local/article_274db950-be01-11e3-a8d4-001a4bcf6878.html |date=April 6, 2014 |access-date=April 8, 2014}} *The SA-211 S-IVB stage was mated with the Skylab underwater training docking adapter and Apollo Telescope Mount and is on display in the Rocket Garden of the [[U.S. Space & Rocket Center]] in Huntsville, Alabama. ==Cost== [[File:Apollo 7 photographed in flight by ALOTS (68-HC-641).jpg|thumb|[[Apollo 7]] heads into orbit with its crew of three, 1968]] In 1972, the cost of a Saturn IB including launch was {{US$|55,000,000|year=1972|round=-6}}.{{cite web |url=https://history.nasa.gov/SP-4221/ch6.htm|title=SP-4221 The Space Shuttle Decision- Chapter 6: Economics and the Shuttle|access-date=2011-01-15|publisher=NASA}} ==See also== * [[Comparison of orbital launchers families]] * [[Comparison of orbital launch systems]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/19710065502_1971065502.pdf |title= Saturn launch vehicles |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20050416215829/https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/19710065502_1971065502.pdf |archivedate= 2005-04-16 |df= }} {{small|(61.2 MB)}} {{Orbital launch
